Award.AwardTitle: IT Catalyst - Equity through Inquiry: ADVANCE at Otterbein University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The PIs at Otterbein College will conduct a self assessment in the areas of bias/climate, service obligations, work-life balance, and issues surrounding invisible women (e.g., adjunct, part-time, those not well integrated into departments.) They will use existing data sources as well as subscribe to the COACHE survey. They will interview women who have left Otterbein, and convene focus groups of invisible women. They plan to institutionalize some data collection efforts. In addition they will utilize the existing mechanism of Professional Learning Communities to bring ADVANCE topics to the faculty. Otterbein is a PUI and aligns their activities well with the specific needs of PUIs. In particular the focus on ?invisible women? is very relevant as many institutions are increasing their non-tenure-track faculty, especially PUIs. Results could prove to have national significance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2012-2015, with the support of the NSF ADVANCE IT-CATALYST grant to Otterbein University, we examined issues of gender stereotypes, service responsibilities, and work-life balance as they pertained to our full-time and part-time faculty, especially women in STEM disciplines. While these topics are generally interesting to many in academia, most pertinent data had been gathered at R1 institutions. Since Otterbein is a primarily-undergraduate institution (PUI), the IT-CATALYST grant provided an opportunity to explore these questions as they pertained to smaller schools. Via analyses of existing campus data and new surveys provided to both full-time and part-time faculty, we obtained a wealth of information with respect to both our entire faculty and our STEM women faculty.

Using national surveys (COACHE), analysis of existing data, and an audit of 5 years of annual performance evaluations, we examined patterns of service among faculty by discipline, gender, and rank, finding that “invisible service” (e.g., appointed ad-hoc committees), rather than “visible” service (e.g., elected committees) was primarily responsible for gender inequities in service responsibilities. We also found that women faculty were advising a disproportionate number of students and student research projects as compared to male faculty. Although small schools are seen as more female-friendly than large institutions, it appears that there are still ways in which small schools hinder the progress of female science professors. One conclusion is that it is important that small schools recognize this and address systematic biases that make it harder for women to be a professor in a STEM discipline. A large proportion of faculty jobs in this country are at PUI institutions and as such it is important to mentor beginning women scientists on how to have a successful career at smaller institutions.  At our institution, data from the COACHE survey as well as the service audit helped inform many changes related to the governance system with an eye on reducing service obligations and helping to ensure a more equitable distribution of work across faculty. The data also suggested that building a stronger STEM community would especially benefit female faculty, so events have been organized to support that goal.

The treatment of contingent or part-time faculty is a vexing issue throughout higher education.  The STEM fields often utilize part-time faculty in laboratory classes. Through an analysis of a survey provided to our part-time faculty, we found that there were part-time people who had worked in this capacity for 10-20 years and were committed to our institution.  This is somewhat different than the more transient contingent faculty at community colleges. It is important for an institution to know who their part-time faculty are in order to better serve them. If our experience generalizes, it is likely that part-time faculty at smaller schools, particularly those that are geographically isolated, have longer histories with the school and high levels of commitment.  This constellation of characteristics leads to a different set of concerns. We identified several concerns related to climate and acknowledged that were relatively easily addressed. For instance, we have implemented a part-time teaching award and provided a guide listing common concerns and questions to all department chairs, who are responsible for hiring part-time faculty. Importantly, we changed our governance system to allow for representation by part-time faculty, giving them actual voice on campus. We also found that some of our part-time faculty are trailing spouses as 31% of our faculty have a spouse in academia. As a result, we joined the emergent Ohio-Pennsylvania-West Virginia Higher Education Recruitment Consortium (HERC). We have reported our findings to offices and committees across campus, working towards a more streamlined set of service expectations, greater clarity with respect to policies for our part-time faculty, and wider awareness of Otterbein’s existing resources with respect to work-life balance. We think these findings are transferable to other institutions with a similar profile and they may provide some guidance as to best practices. We are in progress on a paper to communicate these results.

Overall, the impact of this grant reflects its name (IT-CATALYST) well in that our work became a real catalyst for change. It helped us render the invisible visible to convince others of the need to consider issues particularly relevant to female STEM faculty.  Our results also made clear that smaller institutions are not immune to systematic biases that plague R1 academic departments.  They may manifest differently but have similar effects on the career progress of female STEM faculty.  This knowledge may encourage other small institutions to engage in self-study and also impact career counseling for faculty considering a career at a small institution or those who have already embarked on one.
